text:
Not a lawyer, etc., but have been following this case a bit, so my (possibly flawed) summary:

Previous decisions in this series of cases decided that APIs _are_ copyrightable. However, the current supreme court decision says that writing code that reimplements and/or conforms to that API is not necessarily an infringement of that copyright (i.e., is _fair use_), even if it leads to virtually identical code, because by the nature of APIs, there are a bunch of things where there is really only one way to do it. Or in legal-speak

> Held:  Google’s  copying  of  the  Java  SE  API,  which  included  only  those  lines of code that were needed to allow programmers to put their accrued talents to work in a new and transformative program, was a fair use of that material as a matter of law.

text:
Whether it was a good idea to allow APIs to be copyrightable in general is not entirely obvious. Is there really any creative freedom expressed when writing an API?

Fans of permissive free software licenses might prefer APIs not be copyrightable at all, while FSF-type folks actually prefer the copyright-maximalist approach here, because having APIs be copyrightable increases their leverage with the GPL.

In any case, the overall result (APIs are copyrightable, but reimplementation is fair use) seems like a reasonable-enough compromise to me.
